Politics Picks Up
On JHU Campus
BY ROBERT INSOFT
AND
MITCHELL D. SMITH
With an ever increasing
number of political organizations on campus, students may
wonder if any of these groups
just represent a rehash of the
same philosophies expressed
through other organizations.
While there are many similarities
and common members among
some of these clubs, plans are to
'keep these organizations separate entities. However, students
can expect to see cooperation
between these groups in sponsoring campus events.
The oldest active political
organization at Hopkins is the
College Republicans. Within the
last three years, the CRs have
,sponsored numerous campus
lactivities such as campaign
tparties, voter registration drives,

and in conjunction wipt the
Maryland Republican Party,
have played active roles in
congressional and presidential
elections.
Hopkins CR president Dave
Franchina is optimistic about
the increasing number of political organizations on campus and
feels that they will help give the
students "a wider scope" in
understanding and participating
in American politics. Franchina
also issued a debate challenge
to any other campus group, for
he believes that the political
process is only "brought about
through debate"; so without it,
"politics can't exist."
Soon the CRs, along with
the Jewish Students Association
and the Young Democrats, will
sponsor a lecture on the proposed sale of the AWACS to Saudi
Arabia. Jonathan Kessler from

Tomorrow the All-Peoples Congress will hold a citywide
conference entitled "How We Can Overturn the Reagan Program
of Budget Cuts, Racism and War."
The conference will be held between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.
at St. John's Church, at the corner of 27th and St. Paul streets.
The six-hour event will include speakers, entertainment, panel
discussion, and lunch.
Among the scheduled speakers are Annie Chambers,
a welfare rights activist; Curtis Johnson, president of AFSCME
District Council 92; and many others. There will be panel discussions on such topics as "Tenants Rights and. Housing," "Labor
Rights," "Social Security" and "Energy and the Environment."
Entertainment will be provided by Lucy Murphy and
Archie Stewart. Those who wish to attend are asked to donate
$2.00 to pay for the costs of running the conference. For more
information phone 659-9818.

Hampden Fall Festival
The grand opening of the Avenue Shopping Mall on 36th
Street and Roland Avenue, which will include a pizza-sub shop,
an ice cream parlor, and a record store, will kick off this year's
Hampden Fall Festival.
The fair, which will run from noon until 6 p.m. tomorrow, will be held on 36th Street between Falls Rd. and Chestnut
Ave. There will be rides and games, a flea market, an auction,
and entertainment by the Carroll County Ramblers and Gunpowder Bluegrass. The Miss Hampden Centennial Contest will be held
and the Oriole bird is scheduled to make an appearance.

Inner Harbor Showboat
The Showboat, Baltimore's first floating vessel of musical
entertainment, donated by Omni Cigarettes/Liggett and Myers
Tobacco Company, Inc., will make its musical maiden voyage
along the Inner Harbor's shore Thursday, October 1 and will
continue through October 31, 1981. Every Tuesday through
Sunday from noon to 3 p.m. and 5 p.m. to 8 p.m., the Showboat
will travel the Inner Harbor bulkhead.

We Can't Shrug This Off
There have been so many assassinations in our generation, and so many in the
past year alone, that there is no longer
anything to say about the numbing effect
they have on us. We know that the endless
violence barraging us through the media has
left us unable to react with anything more
than a shrug at each new killing.
Yet there is an aspect of this jaded
attitude, of this having seen the most
horrible twists that one could reasonably
expect to see, that makes us perhaps better
judges of a truly catastrophic event when it
comes along. Part of the reason that we
have been reduced to shrugging at assassinations is that, in a tangible way, they have
had no real effect on our daily lives. While
one could write volumes about how different this country would be today if the
Kennedys and Martin Luther King had
lived, there was little perceptible change for
most people directly after those men were
gone. No state of martial law was declared,
there was no revolution in the streets, and
there was still food on the table.
That may be why the assassination
of Anwar Sadat has caused a somewhat
different reaction than the usual: people
everywhere realize that his death may have
some tangible effect on their lives. Even on
this campus, in such lively political forums
as the Gilman Coffee Shop, one heard more
than the usual cynical remarks when the
news hit.
"Geez, that's really bad," a girl said
to her friend over doughnuts. "I guess all
hell's going to break loose over there now."
Her guess is as good as anyone else's
right now, but if all hell breaks loose over
there, we're going to more than feel the
ripples here. If conversation in the Gilman

Coffee Shop is any indication, we're feeling
the first of them now: fear. Arab and
Jewish Americans, of course, are the most
directly concerned about the sudden
change in the power balance in the Mideast,
but any thinking person should be aware of
how dramatically the killing of Sadat
increases the possibility of war. One can
only hope that for stability's sake, the
newly instated President Mubarak will have
the inclination and the personal strength to
carry through the peace work initiated by
Sadat. If not, a war with Israel could all
too easily escalate into a wider conflict.
But we, as a people who for the most
part have not had to accept guerrilla warfare
in the streets, cannot calculate the willingness of other nations to embrace direct
violence as a means to an end. Just as we
are only dimly perceiving that this assassination will go beyond the others in its
consequences, we are also at a loss to
understand the Arab people who rejoiced
in the streets when they heard Sadat was
dead. We haven't had, and we still don't
have, the same things at stake that they do,
and so we can't understand jubilation as a
reaction to murder. Even those countries
who think they will benefit from this
killing, it seems to us, will do so in the
most bloody way, at great' cost to themselves.
Let's hope that those in a position to
act realize the value of what Sadat was
working for, and try to prevent violence
from becoming the completely accepted
norm. Some of us are still at the point
where violence that affects our lives and
not merely violence that remains contained
to the television set — is still truly horrible.

This past week the world
witnessed yet another tragic
assassination of a great world
leader in Egyptian President
Anwar Sadat. Unsurpassed by
any other world leader presently
in the quest for world peace, his
death may indeed signify "the
beginning of the end" of such a
possibility.
Under the Reagan administration's current "foreign policy," Sadat was primarily viewed
as a militarily strategic, proWestern ally. Surely, this was
one area of his expertise yet, the
true greatness of Anwar Sadat
was exemplified by his moral
obsession with achieving a just
and long-lasting peace in the
Middle East and the rest of the
world.

The most vocal political

Many

students may see the PSU as "a

true of some of the members,
but it is by no means an accurate
description of the organization
as a whole. If you were to ask

what the purpose of the organization was. you would get 65
different answers.
Phillip Schmandt, one of
the students who organized the
PSU last spring, felt that there
was a "political vacuum" at
Johns Hopkins. Schmandt had
been a member of the College
Republicans and the young
Democrats, but he became disil-

interested in their own internal
politics rather than in taking
part in off-campus political
He felt that it was
action.
necessary to create an independent group that is not affiliated
with any national organization.
Schmandt wanted a group in
which students would care about
who was elected president of the
nation instead of who was
elected president of the PSU.
In keeping with these ideals,
the PSU is not affiliated with
any national organization (although it is part of the Progressive Student Network — a loose
communications network of student organizations from about
40 colleges) and the PSU does
not have any president. Meetings are run by a chairman who
is switched every second week.
Having a rotating chairmanship does have disadvantages.
There is no one who can speak
on behalf of the PSU. This leads
to many different and often
conflicting reports on the purpose of the organization. Some
feel that the purpose is to
increase political awareness on
campus; others see the organization as a place where members
can learn about social and
political issues; still others would
like to see the PSU become
involved in lobbying efforts or
electoral.politics.
In some ways the PSU
satisfies all of these purposes.

study groups that research many
issues. The PSU also shows films
and holds forums semi-regularly.
Additionally, the group maintains a literature table to present
information to Hopkins students. Two weeks ago, the PSU
sponsored a dance to raise funds

direction should the group

My education here has taken me
into the studies of behavioral sciences and
Several of my texts have
research.
stressed the need for objectivity on the
part of the scientist in behavioral analysis.
Then is it wrong of me,a long-time fan of
All My Children and One Life to Live, to
analyze and report the habits of soap
opera addicts at Hopkins? Personally I
believe my consanguinity with _Daytime
Drama Dwellers could prove vital in my
analysis of their motives.
When and how does it start? Does
one get "turned onto" soaps by a friend?
Or does afternoon boredom cause one to
reluctantly take in a show, getting the
vulnerable hooked?
Freshman Sara Richmond formed
her habit from peer pressure.
"I felt that if I didn't try it, I
wouldn't be one of them," she says. She
started with the most common afterschool opiate, General Hospital. As often
predicted in such cases, Sara acquired a
tolerance to Gil. Unable to satiate her
needs, she began watching All My
Children and One Life to Live, frequently
termed "harder soaps."
"Yes, I guess it did keep me from
my schoolwork sometimes," Sara recalls.
However, with rehabilitation, Sara Richmond is one of the lucky few who can
take Luke or leave him.
In some extreme cases the habit
started early. Influenced by her sister,
Bonnie Johnson formed a dependency at
12 years of age. However, her addiction
was not as predictable or extensive as
Andrea Murray's. Andrea, although she
did not get involved with soaps until
the tenth grade, spent four hours of her
day charging herself with Ryan's Hope,
All My Children, One Life to Live,
General Hospital, and The Edge ofNight.
Murray and her classmates were attracted
first to Laura of GH.
"She was our age," Andrea
explains, "yet she was starting a relationship with a thirty-five-year-old man."
Clearly identification and idolatry is the
major factor in this case.
Darlene Marshall, actively influenced by her mother, was prescribed
General Hospital to cure her boredom
and depression. By contrast, Raji Mulukutla's inclination to Another World
grew out of rebellion.
"My mother said she didn't want
me watching daytime drama," Raji
explains. "It's like Eve eating the apple.
She made me curious. I figured I had to
try it." Raji's predilection began in
September of 1979, but ended aoruptly
with the start of her college career.
"I don't think I was as dependent
as I thought," Raji comments. "I don't
make time for Mitch Blake anymore."
Unfortunately; not everyone has
an easy time of unhooking themselves
from the afternoon hallucinogen. Many
students have not given up their habits,
nor do they find their dependencies

dangerous. From 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., soap
is bubbling from the television set in the
lounge of Levering Hall. If anyone on
campus has a death wish, existence could
easily be terminated by unplugging the
set or even standing in the way of Luke
and Laura during an intimate moment.
When asked why she was so
violently attached to General Hospital, an
anonymous addict replied,"After following the lives of these people for as long as
I have, they very nearly become real to
me."
Unlike anorexia nervosa, soap
addiction is not limited to those of the
feminine gender. Senior Stephen Steckel
claims to have exposed himself to two
weeks of General Hospital during its most
potent episodes (serious soap users will
recall the "romantic rape" of Laura by
Luke, the man she really loved but
couldn't get involved with because she
was married to another loser, was taking
place at that time. Of course, as everyone
knows, she was begging for it.)
Another male soap addict, sophomore Bob Clayton, is not ashamed to
confess his habit. Bob, like many antisoapers, never took soap seriously, only
watching a few minutes of a serial just for
a good laugh. Influenced by his sister,
Clayton became a devout fanatic and has
been watching All My Children, One Life
to Live and General Hospital for three
years.
Yet another anonymous male
admits to taking in an occasional glimpse
of GH.
"There's nothing wrong with men
watching soaps," he commented. It
certainly is clear that daytime drama is no
longer restricted to the frustrated homebound housewife.
Then there are the classic D-T-D
despisers, who rally against the networks,
claiming the imminent destruction of
Freshman Tamara Williams
minds.
exhausted herself exlaiming, "They're
stupid; the characters are unbelievable
and oversexed."
Sex is a very important compon-

ent in today's soaps, as most fanatics are
well aware (this fact also being a motive
for watching). For example, the necessary ingredients for the successful soap
include one or any combination of the
a
following character descriptions:
prostitute, a prostitute who was a housewife, a housewife who was a prostitute, a
former prostitute now turned housewife
who wants to start her own business at
home, a pun who was formerly a prostitute, a •nun who is a prostitute, and
several prostitutes.
In addition to the sex standards,
there are personality standards: individual representatives of good and evil. The
villain of the old radio soaps has been
transformed into a recognizable human
being. There is the cruel gossip of All My
Children, Erica Kane; the rich witch of
One Life to Live, Dorian Lord; and
Castadine from everybody's favorite,
General Hospital.
Out of all the research and the
interviews, I still did not uncover why
Habitual
soap operas are addictive.
viewers will often admit that the plots are
stupid (if one exists), the acting terrible,
and the dialogue laughable. Still, what
has caused Soap Opera Madness among
so many of America's youth, especially
college students? Do Hopkins premed
students really identify with the competent surgeons of the General Hospital? Is
the Edge ofNight truly a factual image of
American town life?
"I get such a kick out of the little
towns," said one viewer. "Towns like
Center City or Landview or Pine Valley.
Devin is sleeping with Shaun in some
hotel in this town not more than one mile
square. The whole town knows about it.
They probably even synchronize their
watches to the sexual activity. But of
course Devin's husband misses out on the
whole scene."
"I like the way soap opera time
runs," said another. "Three weeks will
pass according to my calendar, but on
One Life to Live it's probably still Thursday."

somehow he would conic back. You sec, he had been thought dead before, but he

Donna, who is the show's former prostitute turned housewife. At fifteen Donna
had her tubes tied secretly during an appendectomy funded by her pimp. Because

episode). However. Chuck didn't like the idea of buying a baby., it seemed too

habit alive. I really wondered how far the
writers could push and manipulate the
limited characters. I honestly believed
they were having a hilarious time forcing
the actors into ridiculous situations —
the whole prostitution cycle, for example. However, I do admit there was some
seriousness involved in my attachment.
Living in New York I ran into some of
my favorite stars in the street. Was it
admiration that made me speechless and
(I'm so ashamed) fawn? As I matured,
I found that I could handle the situation.
Last summer I was bold enough to walk
confidently past the guard and into the
studios of All My Children. I held on to
my dignity when speaking and arguing
with the adulterers Wally McFadden and
Betsy Kenicut, and interrogated the
writers, discovering Sybil Thorne's murderer. Contrary to what I had assumed,
all those I met were rather serious about
what they were doing. Even Erica Kane,
whose role I consider intolerably laughable, retains a straight face as she rehearses her lines.
However, the sad part of soaps is
the serious involvement of the viewer. In
the longest running D-T-D, Search for
Tomorrow, addicts sent flowers and even
dressed for the occasion of a character's
wedding. There is also considerable
anxiety displayed over a character's
well-being.
"No Luke, don't go in there!"
"Nina, don't listen to your father,
you spineless idiot."
"Oh no, Dorian is up to something." These are but a few exclamations
common to the actively involved soap
watcher. Yes, I did leave one out, didn't
I?
"Oh Laura, go on and sleep with
Luke already."

you may be wondering whether there is a
positive side to daytime drama at all?

And
anything on television today.
like regular television, soap does attempt

earthy comedy of the gradual co-opting
of a young Southern Italian into the
"Family." Written and directed by Lina
Wertmuller, the film stars Giancarlo
Giannini.
Mimi, a man, is an idealistic but
none-too-bright construction worker who
doesn't vote the way the mob desires.
Unable to find a job after being blackballed for voting Communist, he leaves
his wife and family behind to find work
in the industrial center of Turin. Living
up to his idealism, he.joins the Communist Party. On hearing of his son's action,
his father accurately exclaims, "He's no
Communist, but a shithead." At a Party
meeting where he is asked to inform
on his employers by a disguised mobster
(all the mobsters have three moles on
their right cheeks), Mimi's fear of mob
retaliation proves stronger than his
idealism. The "Family" puts Mimi down
for possible recruitment. While working
in 'an industrial plant, Mimi takes a
mistress. His courtship of her is amusing
and sometimes ridiculous, as his method
of seduction relies heavily on pathos.

child by his mistress, he once again
encounters the mob. Stepping out into
the lobby of the building, he is witness to
a gangland slaying. When the police
arrive, he knows nothing. The mob notes
Mimi's silence and "rewards" him by
having his firm transfer him back to his
homeland. Mimi is reluctant to return, as

decisive victories, as they all got
on top early in their matches.

two and three doubles spots.

afraid of a letdown.

team was enthusiastic about
playing the Quakers, as all
members were eager to prove
that their fast start was not a
fluke. Fowler also wanted to

test her players' mental toughness against some established
opponents.
"1 he team passed the test,
and the result was a hard-fought,
well-earned 54 victory for

exceptional strength in singles.

pleased with the performance of
Meri-Jo
Nina

We Can't Shrug This Off
There have been so many assassinations in our generation, and so many in the
past year alone, that there is no longer
anything to say about the numbing effect
they have on us. We know that the endless
violence barraging us through the media has
left us unable to react with anything more
than a shrug at each new killing.
Yet there is an aspect of this jaded
attitude, of this having seen the most
horrible twists that one could reasonably
expect to see, that makes us perhaps better
judges of a truly catastrophic event when it
comes along. Part of the reason that we
have been reduced to shrugging at assassinations is that, in a tangible way, they have
had no real effect on our daily lives. While
one could write volumes about how different this country would be today if the
Kennedys and Martin Luther King had
lived, there was little perceptible change for
most people directly after those men were
gone. No state of martial law was declared,
there was no revolution in the streets, and
there was still food on the table.
That may be why the assassination
of Anwar Sadat has caused a somewhat
different reaction than the usual: people
everywhere realize that his death may have
some tangible effect on their lives. Even on
this campus, in such lively political forums
as the Gilman Coffee Shop, one heard more
than the usual cynical remarks when the
news hit.
"Geez, that's really bad," a girl said
to her friend over doughnuts. "I guess all
hell's going to break loose over there now."
Her guess is as good as anyone else's
right now, but if all hell breaks loose over
there, we're going to more than feel the
ripples here. If conversation in the Gilman

Coffee Shop is any indication, we're feeling
the first of them now: fear. Arab and
Jewish Americans, of course, are the most
directly concerned about the sudden
change in the power balance in the Mideast,
but any thinking person should be aware of
how dramatically the killing of Sadat
increases the possibility of war. One can
only hope that for stability's sake, the
newly instated President Mubarak will have
the inclination and the personal strength to
carry through the peace work initiated by
Sadat. If not, a war with Israel could all
too easily escalate into a wider conflict.
But we, as a people who for the most
part have not had to accept guerrilla warfare
in the streets, cannot calculate the willingness of other nations to embrace direct
violence as a means to an end. Just as we
are only dimly perceiving that this assassination will go beyond the others in its
consequences, we are also at a loss to
understand the Arab people who rejoiced
in the streets when they heard Sadat was
dead. We haven't had, and we still don't
have, the same things at stake that they do,
and so we can't understand jubilation as a
reaction to murder. Even those countries
who think they will benefit from this
killing, it seems to us, will do so in the
most bloody way, at great' cost to themselves.
Let's hope that those in a position to
act realize the value of what Sadat was
working for, and try to prevent violence
from becoming the completely accepted
norm. Some of us are still at the point
where violence that affects our lives and
not merely violence that remains contained
to the television set — is still truly horrible.

into the studies of behavioral sciences and
Several of my texts have
research.
stressed the need for objectivity on the
part of the scientist in behavioral analysis.
Then is it wrong of me,a long-time fan of
All My Children and One Life to Live, to
analyze and report the habits of soap
opera addicts at Hopkins? Personally I
believe my consanguinity with _Daytime
Drama Dwellers could prove vital in my
analysis of their motives.
When and how does it start? Does
one get "turned onto" soaps by a friend?
Or does afternoon boredom cause one to
reluctantly take in a show, getting the
vulnerable hooked?
Freshman Sara Richmond formed
her habit from peer pressure.
"I felt that if I didn't try it, I
wouldn't be one of them," she says. She
started with the most common afterschool opiate, General Hospital. As often
predicted in such cases, Sara acquired a
tolerance to Gil. Unable to satiate her
needs, she began watching All My
Children and One Life to Live, frequently
termed "harder soaps."
"Yes, I guess it did keep me from
my schoolwork sometimes," Sara recalls.
However, with rehabilitation, Sara Richmond is one of the lucky few who can
take Luke or leave him.
In some extreme cases the habit
started early. Influenced by her sister,
Bonnie Johnson formed a dependency at
12 years of age. However, her addiction
was not as predictable or extensive as
Andrea Murray's. Andrea, although she
did not get involved with soaps until
the tenth grade, spent four hours of her
day charging herself with Ryan's Hope,
All My Children, One Life to Live,
General Hospital, and The Edge ofNight.
Murray and her classmates were attracted
first to Laura of GH.
"She was our age," Andrea
explains, "yet she was starting a relationship with a thirty-five-year-old man."
Clearly identification and idolatry is the
major factor in this case.
Darlene Marshall, actively influenced by her mother, was prescribed
General Hospital to cure her boredom
and depression. By contrast, Raji Mulukutla's inclination to Another World
grew out of rebellion.
"My mother said she didn't want
me watching daytime drama," Raji
explains. "It's like Eve eating the apple.
She made me curious. I figured I had to
try it." Raji's predilection began in
September of 1979, but ended aoruptly
with the start of her college career.
"I don't think I was as dependent
as I thought," Raji comments. "I don't
make time for Mitch Blake anymore."
Unfortunately; not everyone has
an easy time of unhooking themselves
from the afternoon hallucinogen. Many
students have not given up their habits,
nor do they find their dependencies

dangerous. From 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., soap
is bubbling from the television set in the
lounge of Levering Hall. If anyone on
campus has a death wish, existence could
easily be terminated by unplugging the
set or even standing in the way of Luke
and Laura during an intimate moment.
When asked why she was so
violently attached to General Hospital, an
anonymous addict replied,"After following the lives of these people for as long as
I have, they very nearly become real to
me."
Unlike anorexia nervosa, soap
addiction is not limited to those of the
feminine gender. Senior Stephen Steckel
claims to have exposed himself to two
weeks of General Hospital during its most
potent episodes (serious soap users will
recall the "romantic rape" of Laura by
Luke, the man she really loved but
couldn't get involved with because she
was married to another loser, was taking
place at that time. Of course, as everyone
knows, she was begging for it.)
Another male soap addict, sophomore Bob Clayton, is not ashamed to
confess his habit. Bob, like many antisoapers, never took soap seriously, only
watching a few minutes of a serial just for
a good laugh. Influenced by his sister,
Clayton became a devout fanatic and has
been watching All My Children, One Life
to Live and General Hospital for three
years.
Yet another anonymous male
admits to taking in an occasional glimpse
of GH.
"There's nothing wrong with men
watching soaps," he commented. It
certainly is clear that daytime drama is no
longer restricted to the frustrated homebound housewife.
Then there are the classic D-T-D
despisers, who rally against the networks,
claiming the imminent destruction of

exhausted herself exlaiming, "They're

Out of all the research and the

viewers will often admit that the plots are

has caused Soap Opera Madness among

what they were doing. Even Erica Kane,
whose role I consider intolerably laughable, retains a straight face as she rehearses her lines.
However, the sad part of soaps is
the serious involvement of the viewer. In
the longest running D-T-D, Search for
Tomorrow, addicts sent flowers and even
dressed for the occasion of a character's
wedding. There is also considerable
anxiety displayed over a character's
well-being.
"No Luke, don't go in there!"
"Nina, don't listen to your father,
you spineless idiot."

earthy comedy of the gradual co-opting
of a young Southern Italian into the
"Family." Written and directed by Lina
Wertmuller, the film stars Giancarlo
Giannini.
Mimi, a man, is an idealistic but
none-too-bright construction worker who
doesn't vote the way the mob desires.
Unable to find a job after being blackballed for voting Communist, he leaves
his wife and family behind to find work
in the industrial center of Turin. Living
up to his idealism, he.joins the Communist Party. On hearing of his son's action,
his father accurately exclaims, "He's no
Communist, but a shithead." At a Party
meeting where he is asked to inform
on his employers by a disguised mobster
(all the mobsters have three moles on
their right cheeks), Mimi's fear of mob
retaliation proves stronger than his
idealism. The "Family" puts Mimi down
for possible recruitment. While working
in 'an industrial plant, Mimi takes a
mistress. His courtship of her is amusing
and sometimes ridiculous, as his method
of seduction relies heavily on pathos.

child by his mistress, he once again
encounters the mob. Stepping out into
the lobby of the building, he is witness to
a gangland slaying. When the police
arrive, he knows nothing. The mob notes
Mimi's silence and "rewards" him by
having his firm transfer him back to his

Most of the onlookers at

Jay Women off To Swinging 6-0 Start
BY ELISHA BET-MANSOUR
The women's tennis team is
boasting one of its strongest
starts ever with a 6-0 record. The
team, led by first-year coach
Kay Fowler, appears in excellent
form as it has defeated most of
its opponents decisively. The
team also has one of the tightest
schedules, as it will play twelve
matches in less than a month.
The season started on a very
enthusiastic note September 24
at Trinity as the Blue Jays
gained an easy 7-2 victory. The
team then played host to two
traditional rivals, Widener and
Loyola. The players breezed to
decisive victories, as they all got
on top early in their matches.
Fowler, though excited over
the victories, was skeptical about
.her team's performance. Though
all the members were playing
superb singles, they were not
performing well at the number
two and three doubles spots.
She also believed that. her team
had not been tested yet,and was
afraid of a letdown.
The team was looking forward to its next opponent,
Swarthmore, traditionally one of
Hopkins' toughest rivals. The
team was enthusiastic about
playing the Quakers, as all
members were eager to prove
that their fast start was not a
fluke. Fowler also wanted to

test her players' mental toughness against some established
opponents.
"1 he team passed the test,
and the result was a hard-fought,
well-earned 54 victory for
Hopkins. The Jays won, once
again on the basis of their
exceptional strength in singles.
However, Fowler was also very
pleased with the performance of
Meri-Jo
Nina
and
Urbin
Borzilleri at the number two
doubles spot. She believed that
they could complement the
strong number one team of Amy
Geraldine
Buchanon
and
Klauber very well.
The team continued its
exceptional performance by defeating Goucher at home and
Notre Dame away by 9-0 scores.
Fowler can boast of having
a very strong lineup with exceptional depth. It is headed by
Cheryl Volgelstein, a very competitive, consistent player. A'
transfer student from Trinity.
Geraldine Klauber plays a fluid,
aggressive game. Amy Buchanon
and Nina Urbin both move their
opponents around from the
baseline, and they top off their
talents with very consistent
serves. Men -Jo Borzilleri has
developed a strong serve-andvolley game. There are several
other players whose high level of
performance has been one of the
main reasons for the team's
